statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Knight steps up with 20 points and 10 assists in Bobcats' win
article.story:
CHICAGO (AP) -- The Charlotte Bobcats were sore and short-handed, but that didn't stop them from outhustling the Chicago Bulls. Brevin Knight shook off a bruised right forearm and finished with 20 points and 10 assists, and the Bobcats beat the Bulls 105-92 Tuesday night. Raymond Felton scored a season-high 21 points to go with six assists as the Bobcats (8-18) won for the third time in four games and beat the Bulls for the first time. Gerald Wallace added 19 points, Primoz Brezec finished with 13 points and 10 rebounds, and Keith Bogans and Jumaine Jones added 11 points apiece. "We just wanted to be aggressive," Knight said. "We knew we didn't have our guys inside. We knew we were going to have to get into the paint and make things happen." Unlike the season opener, when they blew a 25-point lead and lost in overtime at the United Center, the Bobcats never let the Bulls (12-12) mount a serious run. After shooting 60 percent from the field and hitting 14 of 17 3-pointers in Saturday's 118-86 win over Boston, the Bulls were 34-of-78 overall and only 9-of-24 from long range. They committed 19 turnovers, were outrebounded 39-35 and fell to 5-6 at home. Chris Duhon did his best to keep the Bulls in it, hitting three 3-pointers in the fourth quarter and finishing with 16 points. Othella Harrington tied a season-high with 16 points. The Bulls hit 18 of 47 shots and were outrebounded 24-17 in the first half, and never turned things around. Power forward Michael Sweetney and center Tyson Chandler committed three fouls in the first half, and Sweetney picked up his fourth 12 seconds into the third quarter. He finished with 12 points and three rebounds before fouling out. "We had mental lapses all over the place," said Chicago's Ben Gordon, who was 4-for-13 with 11 points. After beating Sacramento in overtime Monday, the Bobcats brought more energy despite playing without the injured Emeka Okafor. They led 57-47 at halftime. Bogans' 3 made it 71-60 with about 3:50 left in the third, and the Bobcats' lead stayed in that range the rest of the way. The Bulls cut it to six, but Charlotte answered. They were unable to sustain any momentum, which summarizes their season. "We have had several of those so far," Bulls coach Scott Skiles said. "We cannot have that. We are not good enough to play like that and win. We have to play inspired ball all the time, or this will happen to us." Both teams were missing key players. The Bulls were without leading scorer Luol Deng (14.5 points per game), who sat out after bruising his right knee in Saturday's victory over Boston. An MRI exam taken Monday was negative, and the Bulls hope to have him back Thursday when Cleveland visits. Leading rebounder Okafor and No. 2 scorer Kareem Rush stayed home with injuries. Okafor, averaging 12.9 points and 10.1 rebounds, is expected to sit the next 10 days. An MRI taken Tuesday in Charlotte was negative. He was injured late in the third quarter of Monday's overtime victory over Sacramento when he collided with the Kings' Francisco Garcia while going for a rebound. Okafor rolled around momentarily, grasping his leg, and was unable to put pressure on it as he left. Rush, averaging 13.5 points, aggravated a sprained left index finger that has bothered him on and off for a month. Besides Okafor and Rush (sprained left index finger), forward Melvin Ely (flu-like symptoms) and center Jake Voskuhl (sprained right ankle) did not make the trip. But for one night, anyway, the Bobcats were fine without them. Felton, usually Knight's backup, started at shooting guard and hit 8 of 13 shots. Wallace was 7-of-9 and blocked five shots, and Knight continued his impressive run of late. He is averaging 16.2 points and 9.5 assists in his last 10 games. "(The Bulls) might have thought, 'They're missing Emeka, they're missing Kareem," Felton said. "But they knew we were going to come in and fight."

Game notes
The Bobcats hit 13 of 19 shots and outscored the Bulls 36-28 in the first quarter. The 36 points were a season high for Charlotte and the most by a Bulls opponent in an opening period. ... Charlotte is 1-5 all-time against the Bulls.
